resources.string: Hiragana is the most commonly used form of Japanese letters. Almost all Japanese sounds or letters are composed of zero, one or two consonants and one vowel. Japanese has 5 vowels - a, i, u, e and o.\n

In English, words in a sentence are generally arranged in the following order: 
 Subject + Verb + Object 
 
 However, in Japanese, the order is: 
 
 (Subject) + Object + Verb 
 
 Moreover, subject is not mentioned when it is obvious from the context - especially anata (you) and watashi (I). 
 
 Example: 
 Japanese: 
 Watashi wa hon wo yomu. 
 (I)_________(book)__(read) 
 
 English: 
 I read books.
 
 Generally, Japanese sentences are made up of several noun + particle sequences followed by a verb (or an adjective), which is often followed by a sentence-final particle such as ka (asking a question) and ne (seeking agreement).
 
 Example:
 あした は だいがく へ きます か。
 Ashita wa daigaku e kimasu ka.
 Noun Part. Noun Part. Verb (Part.)
Adding \"masu\" to verbs makes them polite. It is used in formal style conversation.

Examples:
 よみます。(I read/ I will read.)
 Yomimasu.
 
 よみません。(I don't read/ I won't read.)
 Yomimasen.
 
 よみました。(I read/I have read.)
 Yomimashita.
 
 よみませんでした。(I didn't read.)
 Yomimasen deshita.

Letters with dots or a circle:
 Consonants
 k - g
 s - z
 t - d
 h - b, p
 are considered to be related - precisely, the consonants on the right are considered to be a deeper version (with vibration) of the corresponding consonants on the left. Therefore, these consonants are expressed by adding dots or a circle (for p) to the letters of the left-side consonants.
 
 Double consonants:
 Letters with two consonants are written with a letter with "i" sound plus one of や (ya), ゆ (yu) or よ (yo), which is written smaller than when they are by themselves.
